0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Lixisenatide has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU).
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus: initial, 10 mcg SUBQ once daily for 14 days; maintenance, 20 mcg SUBQ once daily starting on day 15; administer within the hour prior to the first meal of the day or the evening meal (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus: missed dose, administer SUBQ within the hour prior to the next meal (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

2.title: Dose Adjustments
2.mono:
• renal impairment: mild (CrCl, 50 to 80 mL/min), no dose adjustment required; moderate (CrCl, 30 to 50 mL/min), use additional caution; severe (CrCl, less than 30 mL/min) or ESRD, use not recommended
  • hepatic impairment: no dose adjustment is required
  • geriatrics: no dose adjustment necessary based on age

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to lixisenatide, metacresol, or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant oral drugs with a narrow therapeutic index, or requiring rapid gastric absorption or careful clinical monitoring; absorption may be reduced; dosage adjustment may be required
  • concomitant use with both basal insulin and sulfonylurea not recommended; increased risk of hypoglycemia
  • dehydration may occur following gastrointestinal adverse reactions (eg, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea); avoid fluid depletion
  • diabetes ketoacidosis; avoid use
  • diabetes mellitus type 1; avoid use
  • gastrointestinal disease, severe (eg, severe gastroparesis); use not recommended
  • hypoglycemia; increased risk with concomitant use of basal insulin or sulfonylurea; dose reduction of concomitant medication may be required; monitoring recommended
  • pancreatitis, history of; acute pancreatitis has occurred with use of glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists; discontinue use if acute pancreatitis suspected and do not restart if confirmed
  • renal impairment, severe (ie, CrCl less than 30 mL/min), or end-stage renal disease; use not recommended

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypoglycemia (combination therapy, 3.4% to 47.2%; monotherapy, 1.7%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (10% or greater), Nausea (26.1%), Vomiting (10.5%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (10% or greater)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Heart failure (0.1%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (0.2%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Lixisenatide is a selective glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist that acts as an incretin mimetic agent to enhance glucose-dependent insulin secretion from the pancreatic beta cells. Therapeutic actions of lixisenatide, via the mechanisms involving cyclic AMP and/or other intracellular signaling pathways, have included enhancement of insulin secretion (glucose-dependent), glucose-dependent suppression of inappropriately high glucagon secretion, and slowing of gastric emptying. In type 2 diabetic patients, lixisenatide improves glycemic control by reducing fasting and postprandial glucose concentrations.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    For subQ injection into the thigh, abdomen, or upper arm only; do not administer IV or IM
  • Subcutaneous
    • available in 10-mcg and 20-mcg solution for injection in prefilled disposable pens and in a treatment initiation pack; 29- to 32-gauge needles not included
    • store refrigerated; after first use, store at room temperature and use within 14 days; do not store with needle attached to the pen; cap the pen to protect from light
    • do not mix with other injectable drugs
    • administer within an hour before any meal of the day; administer with the same meal every day if possible
    • administer oral gastroresistant formulations sensitive to stomach degradation, oral antibiotics, or other oral medications requiring a threshold concentration for efficacy 1 hour before or 4 hours following lixisenatide injection

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: improvements in fasting blood glucose and HbA1c levels are indicative of efficacy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to contact their healthcare provider immediately if symptoms of pancreatitis develop, such as persistent and/or severe abdominal pain.
  • Direct patient to report symptoms of hypoglycemia and to avoid hypoglycemia while driving and using machines, particularly with coadministration of a basal insulin or a sulfonylurea.
  • Advise patient to contact their healthcare provider immediately if symptoms of anaphylaxis occur.
  • Side effects may include nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
  • Severe hypoglycemia may occur, particularly when used in combination with a basal insulin or a sulfonylurea.
  • Direct patient to maintain adequate hydration to prevent dehydration if nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea occur.
  • Advise patient that blood glucose self-monitoring is necessary when used in combination with a sulfonylurea or a basal insulin to adjust the dose of the concomitant drug.
  • Tell patient to inject drug within the hour before the first meal of the day or within the hour before the evening meal.
  • Advise patient to inject drug in the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm.
  • Direct patient to inject drug within the hour before the next meal if they miss a dose. Do not double the dose.
